bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 24, 1904

div1.p: Gorgas writes about the Canal Zone Sanitary Commission, and his wife's illness.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 24, 1904

opener.dateline:
WAR DEPARTMENT
ISTHMIAN CANAL COMMISSION.
Governor's Island N.Y.
September 24th 1904,

div1.p:
Yours of 21st received,
Evidently the man who wrote
the letter for the Herald had read
my letter of transmitted to-
the Commission. The corres-
pondence is on file in both the
Governor's office and in that
of the Commission, so it is
just as apt to have leaked
out there, I do not think
the publication will involve
me in any way with the
Commission
While my position is not altogether
as satisfactory as I had hoped
I believe that we will come
out all right. I will send you
a copy of the sanitary scheme
authorized by the Commission

You will see that they have
authorized the organization
& scheme which I recommended
and had started going,
and have been fairly liberal
in appropriations. I have
just received a most cordial
letter from Gen. Davis hoping
that I will soon be back
to give him my “valuable coop-
eration” So I feel that the
“goose honks high” as far as
Panama is concerned.
Cancer of the breast-
I know that you will be sorry
to hear not such good news from
Mrs. Gorgas. Folk in examin-
ing her last week found that
there had been a return of her trouble
and advised immediate operation.
She entered his hospital and was
operated upon last Wednesday
she sufferred severely from
the ether but is comfortable this
morning. I have asked
authority from the Commis-
sion to remain till Oct. 11th
I will take her to Panama if
she can then travel.

You forgot to send me the
list. Send it and I will
go for my men tooth &
nail.

Mrs. Gorgas asks to join in
best wishes to Mr. Kean

You have entirely won her heart
by kissing her hand when
you last met her.
